transcripts.text: You can't live in this world today and not be curious.  In fact, if ever there was a time to hear from more than the usual suspects, it's now.  This is The Carlos Watson Show.  Maybe we'll surprise you.  Maybe you'll be mad at us sometimes or inspired.  Not only do I hope people will see more with the show, but I hope they'll do more and be more.  People, the good stuff starts now.
Yang Sanity.
Yes.  Tonight, some tough questions for Andrew Yang.  What would you have done differently to actually have won the whole thing?  Now, Andrew breaks news about going to work for Joe Biden.
Joe and I have actually been talking.
Am I hearing Secretary of Commerce?  And who he says killed his 2020 run.
And I thought that was really unfortunate.
Andrew Yang, welcome to the Carlos Watson Show.
Thank you, and congratulations on the new show.
Thank you, thank you.  So, Andrew, take me back and introduce me to young Andrew.  What were you like as a youngster, you know, 8, 9, 10 years old?
Young Andrew was a very nerdy kid.  Bookworm, you would say.  I had the big Coke bottle glasses because they hadn't invented contact lenses or even thin glasses at that point.
Take me through high school.  Still a quiet kid.

Well, I became very emo.  I listened to The Cure and Depeche Mode and I had a skateboard that I rode kind of adequately.  And then my brother went away to college and being sort of competitive, I was like, I should go away too.  So then I went away for the last two years of high school to a boarding school in New Hampshire called Phillips Exeter.  You can imagine like the Asian emo kid showing up to like Dead Poets Society, which is what that was like.
Yeah.
But, you know, like Exeter had a big impact on me.  And I still have friends from my high school days from both schools, really.
How did you end up running for office?  In other words, were you always thinking about politics or is this something that came along later in life?

Oh, gosh, no.  You know, I mean, I tell people that there was no one in the Yang household who was like, you're going to run for president someday.  You know, they were more like, you're terrible.  Clean your room.  Yeah.  My parents were immigrants from Taiwan and politics was not really discussed that much in our house.  So for me, running for president was very much the product of six years running a nonprofit that I started to train entrepreneurs in places like Detroit and Baltimore and Cleveland and New Orleans.  And traveling the country, I saw just how... many people were being left behind.  And I said, well, there's really no way to fix this.  that does not involve rewriting the rules of our economy.  So I said, there's no real way to do this except run for president.  And that's how I ended up running.
All right, Andrew, but come on, because you and I both know that it's not the typical reaction to say things are broken, therefore I'm going to run for president.
This is true.
So really take me in deep.  How did you really decide to do it, and when was that kind of key moment when you were like, I'm in?

So traveling the country, I saw just how many people were being left behind.  But I also got exposed to our political system and the machinery.  And you realize, wow, like the machinery is not actually going to fix these problems.  And when you're with President Obama in the White House or you're with senators and governors, You also start thinking like, wait a minute, like these people are not that different than me.  It's not like they're these like otherworldly figures who, you know, don't put their pants on one leg at a time or whatnot.  And I'm an entrepreneur.  And I thought, well, I believe I can make this case to the American people.  And I'm happy to say that to a large extent, I was proven to be right.  Millions of Americans got behind my campaign and we took the case all the way into the final stages of primary season.

During the Democratic primary season, 23 different candidates appeared on stage at some point.  In fact, it was the most diverse field ever.  Only nine of them were white guys.  But in some ways, that was largely because of the number of women running.  And when Election Day rolled around, the three major non-white candidates had already dropped out.  At the final debate before the Iowa caucuses, Andrew Yang was the only one who wasn't Caucasian.  Did you learn a lot more or shift in how you think about race in one way or another over the course of the campaign?

Well, you always learn a ton when you're campaigning.  I mean, I literally talk to thousands of Americans from every walk of life and every background.  So if you don't learn during that process, there's probably something wrong with you.  You know, I've known for a long time what it's like to be non-white in this country, but you still learn more as you talk to People of color.  in particular, there's this well-known statistic about how maternal mortality is much higher among black moms-to-be.  And there was this one event where a black woman came to me and said that she almost died during childbirth.  Like, it was impossible not to be gripped by this conversation.  And I thought to myself, wow, like, that is... completely messed up.  that someone who should be experiencing childbirth in its purest form instead gets trapped in like this crazy healthcare system that doesn't listen to women of color when they talk about discomfort or pain or medical issues.

And talk to me a little bit about what you've discovered in terms of being Asian, being Asian-American as a public figure, because you were one of the, if you will, groundbreakers in Asian-American conversation in the same way that Jeremy Lin, I'd argue, in professional sports, really kind of offered
it to you.  Yes!  The Jeremy Lin of politics!  You know what?
I kind of like that.  Maybe that should have been the phrase, Yang Sanity.

Yeah, I would have gone all the way with that, Carlos.  But I'm very, very proud of my heritage and to be the first Asian American man to run for president as a Democrat.  I'm... thrilled that millions of Asian Americans around the country got to see someone from our community on the debate stage.  This is the move that we have to make, particularly as technology is now automating away millions of American jobs.  It's why Donald Trump is our president today.  The last person of color, though that itself is its own problem.  I mean, like, I should not have been the last person of color standing.  It's really ridiculous how screwed up our campaign finance system is in particular.  But I'm very, very proud of the fact that I've helped at least some people think that anything is possible for Asian Americans or any American in our country and that we don't have to accept the limitations that maybe some others have put on us, including my parents.  So take that, mom and dad.  I'm kidding.  I'm kidding.

I love that, just going hard at him.  Given the moment that we're going through right now with Black Lives Matter and the whole conversation around racism and social justice, are you optimistic that we're on our way to a better place?  Or sadly, are you like a lot of my friends where you're kind of worried this could be kind of a momentary thing and that we won't get the meaningful change that we're all looking for?

That's our challenge right now, Carlos, is we have to see to it that we get real policy changes across the finish line around police reform for one, around abolishing poverty and taking Martin Luther King's idea of a guaranteed basic income and make that a reality.  Now, one of the answers, it seems to me, is a guaranteed annual income, a guaranteed minimum income for all people and for all families of our country.  particularly right now when tens of millions of us are suffering.  But I could not agree with you more that that's what we should be focused on.  We have to change policy.  We have to change the numbers.  Like if we can't get new rules on the books, then unfortunately people are going to look back on this time and say that nothing fundamental has changed.  That's what we have to keep from being the case.  To me, it's infuriating that we don't have a George Floyd Justice and Policing Act law on the books right now nationwide.

100% agree with you on that.  In 2019, as the race for the Democratic nominee for president filled up with senators and governors and even a vice president, Yang had already thrown his hat in the ring, having spent most of his professional career running a nonprofit.  I feel comfortable saying that this was largely a way to promote his charity or maybe his book or maybe just his big idea.
$1,000 a month for every American adult starting at age 18.
The campaign went from publicity stunt to long shot in February 2019 when he had a two-hour interview on the popular podcast, The Joe Rogan Experience.
Universal basic income.  This is what this is all about.  Yes.
After that, donations poured in, kept tweeting memes, went crowd surfing at events, and eventually the crowds got big enough that he actually looked like someone running for president.
How many of you saw that?  I'm polling at 3% nationwide as of today?

So what surprised you the most?  Now that you've been one of the few people who've actually been a part of a modern campaign, actually been in it to win it, what has surprised you the most?  In fact, if you were going back and talking to Andrew three years ago and you were like, I know you're going to run, and here are the two or three things that are most likely to catch you off guard, what would you have said?

Tops on that list really is the humanity of the process, Carlos, because you go out there and you're away from your family and you're away for days or even weeks on end, and you're there and you're making your case to folks in New Hampshire or Iowa or wherever, there's just like a lot of heart and soul that goes into it.  You know, when you live it, there's like a real kinship you develop with other candidates.  It's really hard being a candidate.  But in my case, the biggest surprise was when you'd go someplace and eventually there were hundreds of people that were really excited about me.  That was like, whoa.  I could not have imagined that when I started the campaign.  I'm a fairly normal guy, and so you don't expect to show up someplace and have a bunch of people holding up posters with your face on it.  You're like, whoa.  Very unanticipated.  And the other thing I'd say, and this is something you're intimately familiar with, is really the role of the media.  Like oftentimes the media had a particular narrative they wanted to push and then they would kind of make the candidates fit the narrative.  And I thought that was unjust to some of the candidates that never really got a chance to.  You know, like there were 24 candidates that ran or even more.  And some of them I thought never got any kind of hearing.  And I thought that was really unfortunate.
Interesting.  Did you ever think that you had a real shot at winning or were you always just trying to make a point that you thought was important?

Well, momentum is one of the most important things in politics.  And there was a point at the end of 2019 where we had this massive surge of momentum.  We were raising as much money and had more energy and enthusiasm behind us than most any other campaign.  And so there was a point when we thought we had a chance to contend and win the whole thing.  And we operated accordingly.  I'm kind of proud to say like there was a choice you had to make is like, hey, are we in this to win this?  Be like, oh, yeah, we're in it to win it.  So we went hard at the early states and tried to do something unprecedented.  And I'm really proud of the fact that we did as well as we did in some of these early states, but we were in it to win it.
And so to take me back, what would you have done differently to actually have won the whole thing?
Well, I would have hung out with you a little bit more.
Then you would have had a good time, but I don't know that you would have won.

But I like that.  But I mean, being really quite serious in that, like, I would have spent more time with journalists to introduce myself because the media had a very, very significant role in how the public perceived me and other candidates.  And the more time I spent with journalists, I think the more they realized I was sincere, and thoughtful and well intended and would give me and my campaign a fair hearing.  I actually did not realize that going in, I did not realize that there were so that there was so much influence in the hands of various journalists.  Most people have still never heard of Andrew Yang.  When they find out about me, oh my gosh.

Andrew Yang's presidential bid was more successful than anyone expected.  He raised over $41 million with a campaign so popular online that the New York Times called him the Internet's favorite candidate.  But after the New Hampshire primary, after receiving less than 3% of the votes and no delegates, Yang dropped out of the presidential race.
We've accomplished so much together.
Talk to me about bowing out.  How did you decide to bow out?  What was that like when you were making the decision?

It was tough.  I mean, again, hundreds of thousands, even millions of Americans had gotten behind my campaign and you feel very responsible to them and obligated and committed to go as far as you humanly can.  But my team sat me down and said, look, here are the numbers.  And I'm the math guy and the math candidate.  So, you know, you look at the numbers.  And then they said, here are the different paths you can take.  And one of them would be to drop out after it was clear that you weren't going to win the nomination.  And I at first thought that was a terrible idea because I thought, well, you know, I'm in this for the long haul and I want to do everything I can to further the movement.  around abolishing poverty, universal basic income, humanizing our economy.  And so I said to them, wouldn't my staying in longer help the movement more?  And then they convinced me that actually, if you drop out earlier when the numbers are clear, then it will help the movement grow, and here is why.  Some breaking news right now from Zareen Shah at Andrew Yang's headquarters there in New Hampshire.  He's dropping out.  His campaign just told us that he is dropping out tonight.  But it was very, very difficult conversation because you're pouring your heart and soul into this for literally years.  You know, you're immensely grateful, but you also feel like you've disappointed folks.  And that's a really tough feeling.
Andrew, where is the Yang gang today?  Where are they?  What are they up to?

Yeah, we're having members of the Yang Gang who are awesome activists and volunteers to my campaign who are now running for Congress and other office.  So I started a new organization, Humanity Forward, that is giving direct economic relief to Americans.  We've already distributed six and a half million dollars directly to Americans during this crisis and the pandemic.  We're supporting local candidates who are running on universal basic income and some of the big ideas.  We're pushing current members of Congress to adopt emergency cash relief, which to me is a no-brainer and a necessity to preserve our way of life, really, and keep us out of a Great Depression.  And we've started something called the Data Dividend Project, ddp4all.com.  And we're trying to say, look, if our data is generating tens of billions of dollars of value a year for Facebook and the big tech companies, why are we not seeing any of that money?  And if you want to get paid for your data, go to ddp4all.com.  So these are some of the things that Humanity Forward is working on.  But I'm busier than ever and the Yang Gang is still growing.  I'm a numbers guy.  I can see the dashboard like the Yang Gang is still growing like a week.
All right, now talk to me about 2021.  Are you gonna throw your hat into the ring in New York for mayor?

I'm focused on making sure.  Joe's our next president.  So that's gonna keep me engaged through the fall.  I hereby am endorsing Joe Biden to be not just the nominee for the Democratic Party, but the next president of the United States.  And there's a chance that I would take a job in the Biden administration And talk to me about that possibility in the Biden administration.
Are there kind of one or two things that you've got your eye on?

Well, I've been very passionate about the fact that our government has been way behind the curve on technology issues, 25 years behind the curve, to be precise, because they actually disbanded the Office of Technology Assessment, who used to advise legislators on technology issues online.
All right.  So you didn't give me an answer.  Am I hearing Secretary of Commerce, CTO, Secretary of Treasury?  Like what one or two roles would really fire you up?

You know, true to the Andrew Yang campaign, Joe and I have actually been talking about a new position that doesn't exist yet, but should around technology and innovation.  But those conversations have been very general.  So to TBD, but we are talking.
All right, finally, rapid-fire questions.  I want quick answers to this.  First question, who is your favorite basketball player of all time?
Larry Johnson.  I just love that guy.
What's your biggest regret?
Wow, biggest regret so far?  Clinging to the Knicks for so long.  No, I'm kidding.
The ultimate question, who is Andrew Yang's celebrity crush?
I have a huge crush on my wife, Evelyn.  And I think she's a celebrity.  She's a star.  And yeah, I've been crushing on her for quite some time.

What a strong answer.  She's clearly the next room.  I love it, Andrew.  You've been terrific.  And I hope you keep coming back.  And I hope you stay involved in politics.  I so appreciate the fresh way that you think about things and your openness clearly to other people.  I hope you keep infusing our politics with that.  I think we'll get to better places if you do.

Well, thank you, man.  I really appreciate that, Carlos.  I'm not going anywhere.  The Yang gang is not going anywhere.  My kids aren't going anywhere.  Let's make this country something we're proud to leave to the next generation.
Thank you.  Thank you.  Look forward to having you back again.
Yeah, let's do it.  We love that.  All right.

Be safe.  Bye, guys.  Hey, so I really hope you enjoyed that conversation with Andrew Yang.  I really enjoyed him from the get-go.  He was kind of warm and funny and kind of wanted to be there.  And who doesn't love a basketball fan?  I'm a basketball junkie, so that was good.  Loved the love affair with his wife and really loved just how relaxed he was.  I've interviewed probably 30, 40 presidential candidates.  He was probably the most relaxed I've ever met.  And last but not least, talk about the guy breaking news.  He and Uncle Joe already talking about a new cabinet position.  That's the good stuff.  Don't only focus on the VP.  There's other stuff at play.  So anyhow, I hope you enjoyed it as much as I did.  See you again soon.  Hey, tune into The Carlos Watson Show.  It's like no other.  You're going to enjoy it every weekday on YouTube.
